summary: the world health organization defines AST or ALT1000 units/liter (U/L) as a criterion for severe dengue. we aimed to assess the clinical relevance and discriminatory value of AST or ALT for dengue hemorrhagic fever. liver enzymes aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) are common in acute dengue illness, occurring in 65–97% of dengue patients. in dengue-endemic countries, dengue is an important cause of acute viral hepatitis [7], [4], [6] and dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) retrospectively reviewed for demographic, serial clinical and laboratory, radiological, treatment, and outcome data. cases were categorized using serial clinical and laboratory data from the entire clinical course as dengue fever (DF), DHF, or dengue shock syndrome (DSS) using WHO 1997 classifications. severe dengue includes severe plasma leakage, severe bleeding, and severe organ impairment. we excluded severe dengue due to isolated elevation of AST or ALT1000 U/L from our definition of severe dengue outcome. patients with pre-existing liver diseases were excluded. the model for end-stage liver disease (MELD) determines three-month mortality based on following formula: 3.8(log serum bilirubin [mg/dL]+11.2(log INR)+9.6(log serum creatinine [mg/dL])+6.4 [17]. chi-square or Fisher's exact test for categorical variables were used to determine statistical significance. by WHO 1997 classification, 38% of patients with DHF/DSS needed close monitoring, while by WHO 2009 classification, 86% of patients with severe dengue required close monitoring. median length of hospital stay was 5 days (IQR: 3–5 days) intravenous fluid was administered to 641 (93%) and platelet transfusion to 86 (12%) death occurred in 1 patient due to pneumonia. AST and ALT were significantly higher during the febrile phase compared to DF or DSS, and for severe dengue by WHO 2009, AST and ALT were significantly higher during the febrile phase. the etiology of elevated aminotransferase levels during acute dengue illness is unclear. AST is expressed in the heart, skeletal muscle, red blood cells, kidneys, brain, and liver. ALT is secreted primarily by the liver [28], [29] because dengue infection can cause acute damage to these non-hepatic tissue types. early diagnosis and proper management may improve outcome in most patients without comorbidities. but in resource-limited countries, patients with severe disease may present late to the hospital with shock, with or without organ impairment.
